p: Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyradiculoneuropathy (CIDP) is an acquired peripheral neuropathy, for which first‐line therapy options include intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg), corticosteroids, and plasma exchange. 1 The degree of treatment response to immunoglobulin differs between patients with CIDP, and the time to and duration of maximum effect can vary from weeks to months. 2 In the IVIg in CIDP Efficacy (ICE) study of 117 patients with CIDP, maintenance treatment with IVIg 1 g/kg every 3 weeks over 24 weeks was shown to be effective 3; however, the European Federation of Neurological Sciences (EFNS)/Peripheral Nerve Society (PNS) 2010 guidelines recommend that the appropriate IVIg maintenance dose and frequency needs to be individualised based on the patient's treatment response, typically at 0.4 to 1.2 g/kg every 2 to 6 weeks. 1
